text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We have seen some nausea in some people. We have some seen some rash, you know a few people ten to fifteen percent. Um we are going to keep a very close eye on your liver function and kidney function to make sure that those weren’t affected by the drug. Uh some people have a uh worsening of their hot flashes, because of the Xtandi itself cause worsening of the hot flashes. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um some people can have a uh decreased energy or they might feel more tired. Um but I, I would have to say in general these side effects are all better than what we see in chemotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So it it it does seem to be the best

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So you’d come in in the morning and you’d get your CT scan and you’d have your bone scan. And two or three hours after the two scans are done you would see me and by that time you would have the results. Have the images on my computer to look at them and discuss the results with you. The other possibility is to do the scans at a local radiology facility and then to get the images with the CDs and have the reports, get them sent to me and have one brought to you physically. But you know like I said if you agree with me, is to do it here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it’s not too much of a hardship. Patient: Very good. If when and needed. Doctor: Yes. And again that might not be for another six to twelve months. It could be sooner, a bit later depending on how or if your PSA increases. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. DOC - investigating new approaches which might not be approved for prostate cancer. Doctor: For prostate cancer. And one of the um trials that we’re doing, which we are quite excited about is this concept of using high doses of testosterone as a therapy for prostate cancer. Patient: As a therapy? Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Well then you mentioned other supplements. Doctor: Right. I think your standard basic multivitamin, it’s a thumbs up. text: Patient: So we’re not going back to C__. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. I got that part of it. Family Member: Is any part of the change in the uh the lymph nodes, would that have anything to do with the testosterone or are you just saying that we’re not hormone sensitive so that probably did exacerbate the situation? Doctor: Well, we’ve been scanning you along the way. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you know when we were on enzalutamide we saw things getting bigger. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it looks like, you know, that’s always a concern with us giving the testosterone, the possibility it could make things worse. It sort of looks like it’s just a continuing monitor. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things are progressing along at a certain pace, and we haven’t really changed the much of that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Slow sort of speak with either thing that we tried.

text: Patient: That’s fine. Doctor: No pain? Patient: I don’t even get the pain when I’m sitting around the house. Doctor: Really? Patient: When I go to sleep at night… Doctor: Okay, maybe it’s not that bad. Okay, push down on mine. Push, push, push. Patient: Push, just push Doctor: Yes. Pull up towards me. (Paper rattling and thumping) Patient: Yeah, no, like I said, at work, I don’t have any problem with walking around, but since, I say, I noticed that I was gettin’ that pain, and it was startin’ to become an irritant to me where I used to didn’t have that problem. You know? Doctor: Now, are you using anything for pain? Patient: No. I didn’t want to do that until I talked to you. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to give you a prescription? Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
